g.text: ‘gap’ in mitigation financing of estimated flows during 2010 to 2012 was slightly under one
More recent published data from the Biennial Assessments
have revised upwards the needs of financing between 2020
and 2030 to 2035 to contain global temperature rise to below 2°C and 1.5°C respectively by 2100: 1.7
(mean) in the Biennial Assessment 2018 for the former, and for the latter,
(mean) for the energy sector alone (and three
times higher if transport and other sectors were
to be included). The resulting estimated gaps in annual mitigation financing during 2014 to 2017, using
published sources was about 67% for 2015, and 76% for the energy
), and greater if other sectors were to be included. While the
annual reported flows of climate financing showed some moderate progress (see Section 15
in the most recent period 2014 to 2017, the gap in financing was reported to have widened considerably
of policy coherence, it is also important to note that reported
annual investments going into the fossil
fuel sectors, oil and gas upstream and coal mining, during the
same period were about the same size as global climate finance, although the absence of
financing and access to low carbon energy is a complicating factor.
Adaptation financing needs, meanwhile, were rising rapidly. The Adaption Gap Report
the current efforts are insufficient to narrow the adaptation finance gap, and
additional adaptation finance is necessary, particularly in developing countries. The gap is expected to
reported actual global public finance flows for adaptation in
The costs of climate disasters meanwhile continued to rise, affecting low
not all necessarily attributable to climate
The institutions under climate finance in this chapter refer to the set of financial actors, instruments and
markets that are recognised to play a key role in financing decisions on climate mitigation and
adaptation. For a definition of climate
financial stock and flows see further Section 15.3 and the
glossary. The issue of climate finance is closely related to the conversation on international cooperation
and the question of how cross
border investments can support climate mitigation and adapt
developing countries. However, the issue is also related to more general questions of how financial
institutions, both public and private, can assess climate risks and opportunities from all investments,
and what roles states, policy makers, regul
ators and markets can play in making them more sustainable.
In particular, the question of the respective roles of the public and private financial actors has become
important in deliberations on climate finance in recent years. The broader macroeconomic c
Four major events and macro trends mark the developments in climate finance
in the previous five years and likely developments in the
First, the 2015 Paris Agreement, with the engagement of
climate agenda has been followed by a series of related developments in financial regulation in
relation to climate change and in particular to the disclosure of climate related financial risk
